data.title: Fixes #9482: AutoClosePair between tags

data.title: Test: Breakpoints updated only after save
data.body:
Test for #8077:
- [x] any OS -  **@sandy081**

New or changed breakpoints are now sent to the debug adapter only after a file has been saved so that they always correspond to the file on disk. Previously breakpoints were sent to the debug adapter immediately even before the file was saved to disk. In this case the debugger would register breakpoints for a source location that only exists in the editor buffer, but not in the file that the runtime sees.

(More details about this feature can be found here: #8077)

**Turn auto save off** and then launch a node debug session and stop on break.
Then verify:
- As long as the file is not edited breakpoints should behave normally, e.g. they are shown as verified, they are hit and can be enabled / disabled, deleted.
- As soon as a file is edited, breakpoints are shown as unverified and the hover message explains why.
- Once a file is saved breakpoints are still unverified (because node-debug does not yet implement hot-code-replacement). The hover message should be slightly different.

data.title: Can't remove unsaved files from a single open editor group
data.body:
1. Have two open editor groups.
2. In one of the panes, create a new Untitled file and make it dirty.
3. Open that file in the other pane, using Quick Open.

The Untitled file is now present in both groups. There seems to be no way to remove that file from a single group. Removing it from the group seems to mean _Closing_ and it will remove it from **all** the groups.

data.title: [Feature Request] HTML Tag matching window
data.body: I recall in webstorm or netbean, when you click on a HTML tag, if the corresponding matching tag is not in current view, a small window appears showing the matching tag as well as a few surrounding lines. It would be great to have this feature.

data.title: Newline break syntax highlighting with const { ... } = this.props
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.4.0-insiders - OS Version: Windows 10 When you have `const { map, coordinate } = this.props` in one line the syntax highlighting works fine for the document, but if you do: ``` const { map, coordinate } = this.props ``` The syntax highlighting breaks for the rest of the document: Fine: Broken: Notice `if` and `var`.

data.title: vscode Extension with edge Problem
data.body:
#### OS Version:win10 x64

Hello Guys,

In vscode extension ,when I require npm package edge , I got some error ,So any help would be appreciated

In the beginning , I got a error as followed:

```
Activating extension `test` failed: %1 is not a valid Win32 application.
c:\Git\test\node_modules\edge\lib\native\win32\ia32\4.1.1\edge_nativeclr.node.
Activating extension `test` failed:  %1 is not a valid Win32 application.
c:\Git\test\node_modules\edge\lib\native\win32\ia32\4.1.1\edge_nativeclr.node
Here is the error stack:  Error: %1 is not a valid Win32 application.
c:\Git\test\node_modules\edge\lib\native\win32\ia32\4.1.1\edge_nativeclr.node
    at Error (native)
    at Object.module.(anonymous function) (ATOM_SHELL_ASAR.js:140:20)
    at Object.module.(anonymous function) [as .node] (ATOM_SHELL_ASAR.js:140:20)
    at Module.load (module.js:355:32)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:310:12)
    at Function.n._load (c:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft VS Code\resources\app\out\vs\workbench\node\pluginHostProcess.js:20:23186)
    at Module.require (module.js:365:17)
    at require (module.js:384:17)
    at Object.<anonymous> (c:\Git\test\node_modules\edge\lib\edge.js:48:8)
    at Module._compile (module.js:434:26)
```

Then I drop the package and run  the command "npm install edge --arch=ia32" ,and then I got a error :

```
The specified module could not be found.
\\?\e:\Docfx\test\extensionTest\jscallTest\node_modules\edge\lib\native\win32\ia32\5.1.0\edge_nativeclr.node
```

and there are a error happen we I reinstall the package

```
Activating extension `jipe.jscall2` failed: Module did not self-register..
Activating extension `jipe.jscall2` failed:  Module did not self-register.
Here is the error stack:  Error: Module did not self-register.
```

Any guidance would be appreciated!

data.body:
> from #4015 by qapi 
- OS Version: OS X

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Run `code folder_1`: Code editor will open on `folder_1`
2. Without closing editor run `code folder_2`: Code editor will not open on `folder_2`, but instead it will focus on editor with `folder_1`

Another example:
1. Run `code folder_1`: Code editor will open on `folder_1`
2. Close editor but do not quit application
3. Run `code folder_2`: Code editor will not open on `folder_2` instead it will open editor with `folder_1`

data.title: Slow scrolling and general usability
data.body:
From @juol in #9197

VSC 1.3.1
OS X 10.10.3

Very slow scrolling and general usability.
All extensions uninstalled.

The slow down is most noticeable in the editor window. Scrolling and moving the caret as well as any selection operations.

When the 1.3.1 update came through the other day the update bar at the top of the editor window stuttered and scrolled down in a few jerky steps.

Expanding a file tree of moderate size is also slow.

It has this behavior regardless of what directory or project I open.

Love VSC and this slow down seems to be pretty rare.
Keep up the great work guys!

Thanks.

data.title: Use require logic for typescript.tsdk
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1

In the `settings.json` you can configure the path for `typescript.tsdk`.
You _can_ use an absolute path which _always_ finds a TypeScript language server (at least if it is available), but you can't have different versions of TypeScript for different projects.
You _can_ use a relative path (like `node_modules/typescript/lib`) which allows you to use different versions of TypeScript for different projects, but it _can't_ find a TypeScript language server, if `node_modules/typescript/lib` isn't in your root (e.g. if you use multi-package repositories or multiple independent examples in one repository).

It would be nice, if vscode could just try to `require` `typescript/lib` relative to the current opened TypeScript file which would probably be the most natural way.

data.title: Command to re-wrap code to respect a preferred line length column (e.g. 80 columns)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.4.0-insider (f4780e67933164a2289b86f2c279aaa05fda672f, 2016-07-19T05:07:05.876Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14390

For example, in Vim, you can select multiple lines of text and type `gq` and lines will be re-wrapped so that they don't exceed the setting for max line length (e.g. 80 columns).

It would be nice to see a similar feature in VS Code especially for wrapping comments, which also has the behavior of correctly inserting a syntax-aware single-line comment token (e.g. //) at the beginning of each wrapped line (and not moving that token into the re-wrapped text of the same lines).

Would also like this functionality to respect the indentation level of the code.

data.title: Ctrl+Shift+F returns to global replace view instead of global find
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.4.0-insider (f4780e67933164a2289b86f2c279aaa05fda672f, 2016-07-19T05:07:05.876Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14390

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open VS Code
2. Ctrl+Shift+H shows Global Replace (in the Search window)
3. Ctrl+Shift+E shows Explorer
4. Ctrl+Shift+F returns to the Search window (but in Global Replace mode instead of Global Find mode)

Expected:

Ctrl+Shift+F should open Search to Global Find mode. (The only way to use the keyboard to switch away from Global Replace is to do Ctrl+Shift+H (or tab to the Replace field) and then press Escape to hide the Replace box.)

data.title: Ctrl+Shift+H Global Search differs in focus behavior from Ctrl+Shift+F
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.4.0-insider (f4780e67933164a2289b86f2c279aaa05fda672f, 2016-07-19T05:07:05.876Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14390

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open VS Code
2. Ctrl+Shift+F to open Global Find
3. Ctrl+Shift+F again returns focus to editor (subsequent invocations toggle focus)
4. Ctrl+Shift+H opens Global Replace
5. Ctrl+Shift+H again does not toggle focus between Global Replace and the editor

data.title: [Request] Enable reopening VS Code to the same workspace and set of files as when VS Code was closed (like Notepad++ default)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.4.0-insider (f4780e67933164a2289b86f2c279aaa05fda672f, 2016-
  07-19T05:07:05.876Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14390

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open VS Code
2. Open some files from disk
3. Open some Untitled editors and make some changes
4. Close VS Code
5. Reopen VS Code

Actual:
Nothing was opened and need to reopen editors (especially frustrating with daily updates to VS Code).
(And no option to change this behavior to opt-in.)

Desired:
The same editors and workplace that was opened when I closed VS Code are reopened so I can continue working where I left off with minimal disruption.
(There should at least be an option to opt-in/opt-out of this behavior.)

Clarifcation:
Should work even if a workspace/folder was not opened (just using VS Code as a text editor).

data.title: Setting "explorer.openEditors.visible": 0 does not actually set the Open Editors view to 0 / hidden
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae, 2016-07-12T13:35:06.227Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14390

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open VS Code
2. Open a bunch of tabs
3. Ctrl+Shift+P "settings" > Open User Settings
4. Set "explorer.openEditors.visible": 0 and save the settings.json file.
5. Observe that the height of the Open Editors view actually gets set to the same as if you had set "explorer.openEditors.visible": 1.
6. Close VS Code
7. Open VS Code
8. Open a bunch of tabs
9. Observe that the number of open editors visible appears to still be one.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/494055/16971870/23148d7e-4ddc-11e6-9bba-6e76ecd2232f.png)

Differs from the change mentioned in https://code.visualstudio.com/updates#vscode "Open Editors View"

Also repros in:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.4.0-insider (f4780e67933164a2289b86f2c279aaa05fda672f, 2016-07-19T05:07:05.876Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14390

data.title: The new @types folder for TypeScript doesn't work on VSCode
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro

Steps to Reproduce:
1. `npm i -D @types/mocha`
2. Create a file.ts with

``` ts
describe('test', () => { })
```

> Error: Cannot find name `describe`

If I build manually with TS it works.

If I do a `typings install --global mocha` instead of `npm i -D @types/mocha` then both VSCode and Webpack work correctly.

Structure

```
├ spec
├─ index.ts
├ src
├─ index.ts
├ tsconfig.json
├ package.json
├ webpack.config.js
```

tsconfig.json

``` json
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "module": "commonjs",
    "target": "es6",
    "noImplicitAny": false,
    "sourceMap": false,
    "typeRoots": ["node_modules/@types"]
  },
  "exclude": [
    "node_modules"
  ]
}
```

webpack.config.js

``` js
module.exports = {
  entry: {
    app: ['babel-polyfill', './src/'],
    test: ['babel-polyfill', './spec/'],
  },
  output: {
    path: __dirname,
    filename: './dist/[name].js',
  },
  resolve: {
    extensions: ['', '.js', '.ts'],
  },
  module: {
    loaders: [{
      test: /\.ts$/, loaders: ['babel-loader', 'ts-loader'], exclude: /node_modules/
    }],
  }
};
```

Dependencies:

``` json
  "devDependencies": {
    "@types/mocha": "^2.2.28",
    "@types/node": "^4.0.30",
    "babel-core": "^6.10.4",
    "babel-loader": "^6.2.4",
    "babel-polyfill": "^6.9.1",
    "babel-preset-es2015": "^6.9.0",
    "babel-preset-stage-0": "^6.5.0",
    "mocha": "^2.5.3",
    "rimraf": "^2.5.3",
    "ts-loader": "^0.8.2",
    "typescript": "^2.0.0",
    "webpack": "^1.13.1"
  }
```

data.title: UX meeting agenda July 20, 2016
data.body:
**Agenda:**

TABS / OPEN EDITORS
- Closing dirty editor prompts for save (even when there are other duplicate editors open) #8983
- Debug toolbar in the way of tabs (move it?) #9093 
- Quick Open preview, launched editors should stay open #8939 
- "Left, "right," "center" take up too much space?  Need to validate this #8961

OTHER
- San Fransisco font issues in Chromium (upstream problem affecting UX) #9152
- Hard to place caret before first character when folding enabled.  #8871
